trans-unit.source: Implements a selectable item inside a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.ComboBox"></xref>.
> [!NOTE] > By default, the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.HorizontalAlignment%2A> of a ComboBoxItem is set to <xref:System.Windows.HorizontalAlignment>.
The default horizontal position of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.StackPanel> is <xref:System.Windows.HorizontalAlignment>.

If you set the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Width%2A> property of a ComboBoxItem through a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.StackPanel>, the panel's default is applied and the item will be centered.
A ComboBoxItem is a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContentControl>, which means that it can contain a single object of any type (such as a string, an image, or a panel).
For more information, see the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContentControl> class.
Customizing the ComboBoxItem Control To apply the same property settings to multiple ComboBoxItem controls, use the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Style%2A> property.
You can modify the default <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> to give the control a unique appearance.

For more information about creating a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate>, see [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
To see the parts and states that are specific to the ComboBoxItem, see [ComboBox Styles and Templates](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
Dependency properties for this control might be set by the controlâ€™s default style.
If a property is set by a default style, the property might change from its default value when the control appears in the application.
The default style is determined by which desktop theme is used when the application is running.
For more information, see [Default WPF Themes](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=158252).
> [!NOTE] > Setting a visual property will only have an effect if that property is both present in ComboBoxItem control's default template and is set by using a .

You can find a list of visual properties in the "Changing the Visual Structure of a Control" section in [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](../Topic/Customizing%20the%20Appearance%20of%20an%20Existing%20Control%20by%20Creating%20a%20ControlTemplate.md).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.ComboBoxItem"></xref> class
Gets a value that indicates whether the item is highlighted.
This property can be used by styles that need a highlight to indicate selection.
Starting with the .NET Framework version 3.0 Service Pack 1, IsHighlighted has a protected setter.
To use this functionality, your application should target the .NET Framework version 3.5.
For more information, see [Versions and Dependencies](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier Field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if a <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.ComboBoxItem"></xref> is highlighted; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Identifies the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ComboBoxItem.IsHighlighted*> dependency property.
To be added.
Called when the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContentControl.Content*> property changes.

Responds to a <xref href="System.Windows.UIElement.MouseEnter"></xref> event.
Provides data for <xref href="System.Windows.Input.MouseEventArgs"></xref>.
Responds to the <xref href="System.Windows.UIElement.MouseLeftButtonDown"></xref> event.
Provides data for <xref href="System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs"></xref>.
Responds to the <xref href="System.Windows.UIElement.MouseLeftButtonUp"></xref> event.
Provides data for <xref href="System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs"></xref>.
